title: Jurimetrics
text:
Jurimetrics is the application of quantitative methods, and often especially <a href="Probability%20theory">probability</a> and <a href="statistics">statistics</a>, to <a href="law">law</a>. In the United States, the journal "<a href="Jurimetrics%20%28journal%29">Jurimetrics</a>" is published by the <a href="American%20Bar%20Association">American Bar Association</a> and <a href="Arizona%20State%20University">Arizona State University</a>. The "<a href="Journal%20of%20Empirical%20Legal%20Studies">Journal of Empirical Legal Studies</a>" is another publication that emphasizes the statistical analysis of law.
The term was coined in 1949 by <a href="Lee%20Loevinger">Lee Loevinger</a> in his article "Jurimetrics: The Next Step Forward". Showing the influence of <a href="Oliver%20Wendell%20Holmes%2C%20Jr.">Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr.</a>, Loevinger quoted Holmes' celebrated phrase that:
The first work on this topic is attributed to <a href="Nicolaus%20I%20Bernoulli">Nicolaus I Bernoulli</a> in his doctoral dissertation "De Usu Artis Conjectandi in Jure", written in 1709.
Applications.
Gender quotas on corporate boards.
In 2018, California's <a href="California%20State%20Legislature">legislature</a> passed Senate Bill 826, which requires all publicly held corporations based in the state to have a <a href="Gender%20representation%20on%20corporate%20boards%20of%20directors%23Gender%20quotas">minimum number of women</a> on their <a href="board%20of%20directors">board of directors</a>. Boards with five or fewer members must have at least two women, while boards with six or more members must have at least three women.
Using the <a href="binomial%20distribution">binomial distribution</a>, we may compute what the probability is of violating the rule laid out in Senate Bill 826 by the number of board members. Screening of drug users, mass shooters, and terrorists.
In recent years, there has been a growing interest in the use of <a href="Screening%20%28medicine%29">screening tests</a> to identify <a href="Drug%20testing%20welfare%20recipients">drug users on welfare</a>, potential <a href="Mass%20shootings%20in%20the%20United%20States">mass shooters</a>, and <a href="Terrorist%20Screening%20Database">terrorists</a>. The efficacy of screening tests can be analyzed using Bayes' theorem.
Suppose that there is some binary screening procedure for an action formula_25 that identifies a person as testing positive formula_26 or negative formula_27 for the action. Even with very high sensitivity and specificity, the screening tests only return posterior probabilities of 60.1% and 0.98% respectively for each action. Under more realistic circumstances, it is likely that screening would prove even less useful than under these hypothetical conditions. The problem with any screening procedure for <a href="rare%20events">rare events</a> is that it is very likely to be too imprecise, which will <a href="False%20positives%20and%20false%20negatives%23False%20positive%20error">identify too many</a> people of being at risk of engaging in some undesirable action.
Jurimetrics and law and economics.
The difference between jurimetrics and <a href="Law%20and%20Economics">law and economics</a> is that jurimetrics investigates legal questions from a probabilistic/statistical point of view, while <a href="Law%20and%20Economics">law and economics</a> addresses legal questions using standard <a href="Microeconomics">microeconomic analysis</a>. A synthesis of these fields is possible through the use of <a href="econometrics">econometrics</a> (statistics for economic analysis) and other <a href="Mathematical%20economics">quantitative methods</a> to answer relevant legal matters. As an example, the Columbia University scholar <a href="Edgardo%20Buscaglia">Edgardo Buscaglia</a> published several peer-reviewed articles by using a joint jurimetrics and <a href="Law%20and%20Economics">law and economics</a> approach.
